misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 (so the first element is at index 1 and the last element is at index arraySize), and therefore loops should run from 1..arraySize inclusive.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0 to arraySize-1. Using 1..arraySize causes attempts to access userInputArray[arraySize], which is out of bounds, and also leaves index 0 unused/uninitialized. This breaks both input storage and the shift operation.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException during input (and also during shifting if it got that far).

evidence.code_snippet: int currentIndex = 1; // I will start from 1 because I want to count all elements in a human way
while (currentIndex <= arraySize) {
userInputArray[currentIndex] = userInputValue; // I think index currentIndex should match the element number
int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySize];
int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
userInputArray[1] = lastElementTemporaryHolder;
int printIndex = 1; // Start from 1 because I think the first element is at position 1
while (printIndex <= arraySize) {
int valueToPrintTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[printIndex];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that arrays in Java are indexed starting from 1 (like human counting), rather than starting from 0. They think 'element number 1' corresponds to array index 1, and the first position in an array is at index 1 rather than index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays use 0-based indexing, where valid indices range from 0 to length-1. The student's mental model treats arrays as 1-indexed, causing them to skip the element at index 0 and attempt to access index positions that don't exist. When they try to access userInputArray[arraySize], they are reading beyond the array bounds (which is undefined behavior for uninitialized memory in this context).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The code will produce incorrect output or a runtime ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. Even if no exception occurs, the first element will not be read or shifted correctly, and attempting to store elements at index positions 1 through arraySize will leave index 0 uninitialized and cause the shift logic to fail.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java are 1-based, matching human counting, where the first element is at index 1 and the last element is at an index equal to the array's size.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed. An array of size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. Attempting to access index N results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, and the element at index 0 remains unutilized or incorrectly ignored.

userInputArray[1] = lastElementTemporaryHolder;

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based indexing applied to Java arrays (array bounds misconception)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 (so the first element is at index 1 and the last element is at index N), and that looping from 1..N is valid for an array of length N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0 through (length - 1). For an array created with new int[arraySize], the last valid index is arraySize - 1, not arraySize. Using indices 1..arraySize both skips index 0 and attempts to access index arraySize, which triggers an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime error (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) for any arraySize > 0; therefore the program does not produce the required shifted output.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed starting from 1 (like human counting), so an array of size N has positions 1, 2, 3, ..., N. They treat the first element as being at position 1, the last at position N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java uses 0-based indexing. An array of size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. The student has confused Java arrays with 1-indexed languages or natural counting, leading to systematic off-by-one errors throughout the code. Index 0 is the first position, not index 1.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when the code attempts to access userInputArray[arraySize] and when reading input into userInputArray[currentIndex] starting at 1. The code would crash before producing any output.

evidence.code_snippet: int currentIndex = 1; // I will start from 1 because I want to count all elements in a human way

int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySize];
int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
int printIndex = 1; // Start from 1 because I think the first element is at position 1

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 and ending at the size of the array (N), mapping directly to natural human counting rather than the zero-based (0 to N-1) system.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array indices are zero-based. An array of size N has valid indices from 0 up to N-1. By starting at 1 and attempting to access index N, the student attempts to access a memory location outside the allocated bounds of the array, while simultaneously ignoring the valid 0th index.
